conclusion: Problem involves finding when a particle is farthest from the starting point based on acceleration and velocity graphs.
Acceleration graph is a triangular wave: starts at zero, peaks at a₀ at t₀/2, zero at t₀, -a₀ at 3t₀/2, and zero at 2t₀.
Particle starts from rest, meaning initial velocity is zero.
Velocity changes according to acceleration: increases with positive acceleration, decreases with negative.
Velocity graph shows increase to a maximum at t=t₀, then decreases back to zero at t=2t₀.
Key is finding when particle changes direction, indicating it's farthest from starting point.
Particle is farthest when velocity changes from positive to negative.
Velocity should decrease to zero when acceleration becomes negative after t=t₀.
Acceleration is positive and increasing from t=0 to t₀/2, decreases from a₀ to -a₀ from t₀/2 to 3t₀/2, increases back to zero from 3t₀/2 to 2t₀.
Integrating acceleration gives the velocity graph.
Integrate acceleration from t=0 to t₀/2: a(t) = (2 a₀ / t₀) t, v(t) = (a₀ / t₀) t² + C, C=0 at t=0.
